text: I was leading the the global summit of
the the main countries in the world at
Gleneagles in Scotland we'd literally
just had the news about the Olympic bid
and winning the Olympics for London so
there was a general state of euphoria
and then I remember having a meeting
about the summit with the Chinese
president and being passed a note in the
course of that meeting saying that
they've been instance on the London
Underground and that I should step out
of the meeting and which I then did and
started to take calls and then as as the
minutes progressed it became pretty
obvious quickly that this was a
terrorist attack and at that time we
didn't know the full extent of it but as
the morning went on it became clear
there were there were multiple
casualties and did you at any moment
think in any way that you were partly
culpable because of Iraq because of
Afghanistan look at the time the single
most important thing is that you think
as to how you can deal with the
situation right so this is the the first
thing that you're talking about now
later as time goes on you're able to
reflect I think it's very important to
understand that the probable leader of
the seven seven attacks was someone who
was first in the training camp in the
middle of 2001 before 9/11 never mind
before the invasion of Afghanistan or
the invasion of Iraq and you know the
the difficulty is that there will always
be reasons and excuses that people use
for terrorism and you have countries
like France today that's the subject of
terrorism or Norway or Belgium or
Tunisia or Kuwait or countries across
Africa none of whom had anything to do
with British or American foreign policy
and yet whose citizens come under this
type of violent and indiscriminate
killing so you know I think in the end
the responsibility has got to live with
the people who carry this out and those
who encourage them
